results.headline: Saving the Earth With a Quasi-Human Partner

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Evangelion: 1.0 You Are (Not) Alone

results.summary_short: “Evangelion 1.0: You Are (Not) Alone” is just another giant-robot story.

results.headline: A Yummy Forecast

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs

results.summary_short: “Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs” is a tale of youthful ambition, love and the quest for approval.

results.headline: A Portrait of a Photographer
results.display_title: If One Thing Matters: A Film About Wolfgang Tillmans

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of If One Thing Matters: A Film About Wolfgang Tillmans

results.summary_short: You wait a long, long while in “If One Thing Matters: A Film About Wolfgang Tillmans” for Mr. Tillmans to say anything vaguely related to his art.

results.headline: A Sick Man Embracing a City’s Life, Just as His Own Is Threatened

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paris

results.summary_short: Although “Paris” makes gestures toward being a top-to-bottom examination of the city’s social fabric, its perspective is solidly middle class.

results.headline: This Self-Help Expert Could Use Some Help

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love Happens

results.summary_short: The vital signs in “Love Happens,” a movie that feels likes a laboriously padded outline, are faint.

results.headline: Hell Is Other People, Especially the Popular Girl

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jennifer's Body

results.summary_short: “Jennifer’s Body” takes up a common theme of slasher films — that queasy, panicky fascination with female sexuality that we all know — and turns it inside out.

results.headline: Wearing Heartbreak Like a Badge

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harmony and Me

results.summary_short: “Harmony and Me” is a low-fi comedy of sulks and self-pity.

results.headline: A Story of Loss, Guilt and Barbecued Birds

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Burning Plain

results.summary_short: “The Burning Plain” depends on ideas about human behavior that can only be called preposterous.

results.headline: Struggling to Decipher International Relations and Individual Lives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 35 Shots of Rum

results.summary_short: “35 Shots of Rum” is a quiet and lovely new film by the French director Claire Denis.

results.headline: Keats and His Beloved in an Ode to Hot English Chastity

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bright Star

results.summary_short: The achievement of Jane Campion’s learned and ravishing new film is to trace the comminglings and collisions of poetic creation and amatory passion.

results.headline: Modern-Day Slavery, the People and Politics

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fatal Promises

results.summary_short: “Fatal Promises” lacks focus and adds little to the awareness of the subject that even a casual follower of the news has already acquired.

results.headline: The Untold Story of a War, and the Story of the Man Who Told It
results.display_title: The Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers

results.summary_short: This detailed, clearly told and persuasive film is about Daniel Ellsberg, the man who leaked the secret history of the Vietnam War, known as the Pentagon Papers, to newspapers.

results.summary_short: In “Tyler Perry’s I Can Do Bad All by Myself,” which opened on Friday, Mr. Perry has his moviemaking machine running smoothly, which is to say somewhat predictably.

results.headline: Sisterhood of Trash-Talking Pranksters

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sorority Row

results.summary_short: “Sorority Row” salivates over the gory consequences of blabbing after some very bad behavior by several Theta Pi sisters who have sworn to stay mum.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Walt & El Grupo

results.summary_short: “Walt & El Grupo” is a relentlessly upbeat vanity project destined for the Disney family archive.

results.summary_short: The ever-popular question “What does it mean to be Jewish?” gets another parsing in “Rashevski’s Tango.”

results.summary_short: “Whiteout” has a perfunctory, by-the-numbers approach to its story and its characters.

results.summary_short: “Skiptracers,” a good-ol’-boy comedy set in Alabama, drifts along telling yuk-yuk stories about a cast of cartoonish Southern eccentrics.
